cyclone.name: IDALIA
cyclone.current_location: about 85 miles north of the western tip of Cuba and 370 miles south-southwest of Tampa, Florida
cyclone.trajectory: moving north today, then accelerating north-northeast across the eastern Gulf toward Florida’s Big Bend on Wednesday and onward across southeast Georgia and the Carolinas, emerging offshore near the North Carolina–Virginia border late Thursday night
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: Florida Big Bend near or just south of Cedar Key

weather_observation.watch_coast: Storm Surge and Tropical Storm Watches currently extend only from the mouth of the St. Mary’s River, FL to South Santee River, SC – no watches yet north of Cape Fear.
weather_observation.warning_coast: Hurricane and Storm-Surge Warnings confined to Florida Gulf coast (Englewood to Indian Pass including Tampa Bay).
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Florida Gulf coast (Big Bend), southeast Georgia, the South and North Carolina coasts, with lesser effects potentially reaching the southern Chesapeake Bay and Virginia Capes.
weather_observation.wind: Low (≤3%) chance of sustained tropical-storm-force winds; any winds above gale force would be brief late Thursday night or early Friday while the center passes offshore.
weather_observation.storm_surge: At this time guidance keeps surge below 3 ft along the lower Chesapeake and Virginia Capes; only minor coastal inundation possible with persistent onshore flow.
weather_observation.rainfall: 1–3 inches of rain possible Thursday night–Friday, locally higher in heavy bands, enough to cause ponding and minor terminal/yard flooding.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Dangerous rip currents and rough seas beginning Thursday; potential short-notice tornado threat in outer rainbands as the center nears the North Carolina-Virginia border.
